{{distinguish|Guardians of Peace}} The '''Guardians of the Peace''' ({{lang-fr|Gardiens de la Paix}}) were a pro-government [[paramilitary]] [[militia]] active in [[Burundi]] during the [[Burundian Civil War]] (1993–2006). It is believed to have existed between 1997 and 2005.<ref name=UM>{{cite web|title=Guardians of Peace (Burundi)|url=http://www.sowi.uni-mannheim.de/militias-public/data/pgag/10/|work=Pro-Government Militias Database (PGMD) Project|publisher=University of Mannheim|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> According to the government, the militia was primarily intended to secure the rural areas against rebel groups as part of a policy of "civilian self-defence". Its members were armed but not uniformed.<ref>{{cite news|title=More than 2,500 armed "guardians of the peace" emerge in south Burundi|agency=AFP|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/burundi/more-2500-armed-guardians-peace-emerge-south-burundi|publisher=Relief Web|date=21 May 2000|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> It was founded by Colonel Ascension Twagiramungu and is believed to have recruited primarily among adolescents, children and former anti-government rebels in rural Burundi.<ref name=UM/> Although recognised as a semi-official organisation, the Guardians of the Peace were never a single entity and instead consisted of autonomous regional groups.<ref name=UM/>
Founded in 1997, Guardians of the Peace from across Burundi were deployed to [[Bujumbura]] during its siege by [[National Forces of Liberation]] (FLN) rebels in 2000. The Guardians of the Peace sustained heavy casualties.<ref name=HRW>{{cite web|title=Expansion of the Guardians of the Peace|url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/2001/burundi/burundi1201-09.htm|publisher=Human Rights Watch|work=To Protect the People: The Government-sponsored "self-defense" program in Burundi|year=2001|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> They expanded rapidly in size during the escalation of the Civil War in 2001. Both FLN and [[National Council for the Defense of Democracy – Forces for the Defense of Democracy|Forces for the Defense of Democracy]] (FDD) rebels specifically targeted individual members of the organisation in order to intimidate other Guardians of the Peace.<ref name=HRW/> It is estimated that as many as 30,000 Burundians received training as Guardians of the Peace during the period.<ref name=HRW/> In [[Bururi Province]], it was estimated that there were 5,000 active Guardians of the Peace with smaller numbers in other regional groups.<ref name=HRW/>
The government begun the demobilisation of the Guardians of the Peace in 2003 and the process was finally completed on 30 September 2005.<ref name=UM/>
